{"title":"Section 5, Page 5","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"Mr Cohen further reported that the survey of the section from Thibodaux

By appointment of the Committee, Maj. Blanciiard had prepared a Report,!
which was printed for use, but from the greater length of his line, and other causes
explained by him, lie had not had time to have his sketch of the road lithographed.
The Committee, fearing that Maj. Blanciiard would not have time to make
an actual survey of all the lines of his section; requested Messrs. Flanders
and Seger to examine the proposed line south of Lake Des Allcmands, as far
as Bayou Des Allemands. The result of their examination is most cheering,
as will appear from their Report,*}: which was handed in.
Mr. B. Buisson, Surveyor, by request, prepared a topographical map of
the country between New Orleans and Berwick's Bay. On the proposed
railroad line, running as marked on his map, north of Lake Des Allemands,
there is, he says in his letter to the Committee, no pi'airie and less bridging
than on any other.
Maj. Blanchard concluded his Report by congratulating him (Mr- C.) on
the favorable result of his survey; and ho begged leave to conclude his Report
by congratulating the Convention on the favorable result of all the surveys.
Now, he could, with great truth, congratulate them on the favorable result
of each and every movement in behalf of this road, from their adjournment in
•lane last, up to this moment. He would ask to remind Mr. H. Lawrence,
Ul, Payne, Mr. Stanton and Mr. Nichols, of the meeting of that small band
ot friends who conversed in the little back room of the Crescent Insurance Office
u Way last. Did they not remember how he, as Chairman, on that occasion,
ouched tenderly the idea of a western extension, fearing that it might cause
whole scheme to be regarded as visionary; how he cautiously broached the
object of crossing the Sabine to Texas, and of crossing Texas to El Paso, lest
e enterprize should be sneered at as chimerical ? But, now, he congratu-
1 es them, and all, that recent developements in Texas and elsewhere have
a so numerous and enthusiastic, that the prolongation of the road is now
garded by all as probable, and by many as certain.
t °°d and sufficient cause had he, then, to felicitate them on the proud
Je on which, at this day, their prospects repose ; not tremulously, but
ely and triumphantly. All mists and misgivings have been dispersed by

I*R- He said to them, in June last, that the road shall be built; and he
o them, now, that it will be built, surely and speedily, and to the eternal
